explanation:
Correct calculation: \(5\ \text{liters} \times 1000\ \mathrm{cm}^3/\text{liter} = 5000\ \mathrm{cm}^3\).

Incorrect calculation: \(5 \times 100 = 500\).

The student incorrectly multiplied by 100 instead of 1000. This stems from misapplying the conversion factor between liters and cubic centimeters, likely confusing the cubic decimeter relationship. Since \(1\ \text{liter} = 1\ \mathrm{dm}^3\) and \(1\ \mathrm{dm} = 10\ \mathrm{cm}\), the correct volume conversion requires cubing the linear factor: \(10^3 = 1000\). The student used \(10 \times 10 = 100\), treating it as a square relationship rather than a cubic one. This distinguishes the error from dividing by 100 (which would reverse the conversion direction) or using \(1\ \text{liter} = 10\ \mathrm{cm}^3\) (which would yield 50).
